text: I agree with Professor Dye that Qur'anic Arabic is full of loanshifts and calques from neighboring languages, which are always a sign of the author's multilinguality.  The Qur'an's use of the Aramaic melta (milla) to mean Logos is evidence he knew Greek

text: 1/28   These conclusions underpin my new book, "Muhammad: Prophet of Peace amid the Clash of Empires'
author: jricole

text: 1/27  But it seems clear that the post-Muhammad Muslims came into conflict with the Romans/ Byzantines from the mid-630s forward.  If the Qur'an were post-Muhammad it would have passages reflecting this reevaluation of the alliance with Constantinople.  It does not.
author: jricole

text: 1/26 As for the notion that the Qur'an continued being produced by a folk process after Muhammad, I find it completely implausible.  The Qur'an favors the Romans in the war with Khosrow II, throughout the book.
author: jricole

text: Just to clarify that Zubayrids were Asadi; it is a different family mentioned as Zuhri
author: jricole

text: 1/25 and that the Qur'an's milieu was in fact sometimes Palestine/ Syria because Muhammad preached to audiences there under Sasanian occupation in 616-17 (Jacob of Edessa).  Muhammad could have been exposed to local Pal. traditions, but some are actually just Hellenism
author: jricole

text: 1/24   In short, the epigraphic evidence for the Hijaz as the site of the Qur'an is now powerful and the more we know about late Antiquity the more plausible it is that a single well-traveled, polyglot religious seeker could easily have been the vehicle for the Qur'an
author: jricole

text: 1/23  Furthermore, Christian sources such as Jacob of Edessa (d. 699) say Muhammad went on traveling after receiving his prophetic mission.  I think the Qur'an gives evidence for familiarity with Petra and Jerusalem and the sources say he went to Bostra and Damascus for trade
author: jricole

text: 1/22  The discovery and publication of the Petra Papyri shows that Arabic-speaking families in NW Arabia & Transjordan used Greek for formal purposes and probably Aramaic for local ones;  Arab Hellenism was widespread
author: jricole

text: 1/21  But Sulaiman A. Mourad has shown that the story of Mary giving birth at the palm tree is a Christianization of the myth of Leto giving birth to Apollo on Delos; the Qur'an's adoption of it may precede the Christian!  https://sophia.smith.edu/~smourad/SA%20Mourad--From%20Hellenism%20to%20Christianity%20&%20Islam%20Origin%20of%20Palm%20Tree%20in%20Quran.pdf …
author: jricole

text: 1/20  @GuillaumeDye furthered Shoemaker's analysis, suggesting that Surah 19 must have been authored by someone other than Muhammad.
author: jricole

text: 1/19  Shoemaker argued that this church was associated with local knowledge traditions such as Mary giving birth on a palm tree 19:24-25 and that the Qur'an must have gotten this story from the Theotokos church tradition
author: jricole

text: 1/18 Stephen J. Shoemaker attempted to revive a Palestinian context for the Qur'an with an article on local knowledge traditions of the  Kathisma of theTheotokos of Kathisma church between Bethlehem and Jerusalem
author: jricole

text: 1/17  One of these inscriptions is dated 699/700 AD and mentions Muhammad, who died in 632.   Crone was just wrong that the Hijaz was a secondary center
author: jricole

text: 1/16  But now many rock inscriptions have been found around Medina from the grandchildren and descendants of al-Zubayr ibn al-`Awamm, a cousin of the Prophet Muhammad; and one gives the nisba al-Zuhri, a sept of the Quraysh.
author: jricole

text: 1/15  But the argument from silence has long struck me as insubstantial.  Ancient Greek geographers didn't mention a lot of places, and the importance of central places changes over time.  Even if Maccoraba in Ptolemy isn't Mecca, it doesn't matter.
author: jricole

text: 1/14  It has also been argued that Mecca is not mentioned by Greek geographers before Islam, and that Safaitic inscriptions don't mention Quraysh.
author: jricole

text: 1/13  I've never understood why she thought Medina emerged as the capital of the first Muslim state; or maybe she even rejected that.
author: jricole

text: 1/12 Cook I think fairly quickly moved away from the positions of Hagarism such that the Qur'an came out of a Palestinian Jewish sect, then moved to Samaritanism, then to incorporating Christianity.  But Crone kept them longer.
author: jricole

text: 1/11  One of their pieces of evidence for 'the shine at Mecca having been secondary' (in favor of Hebron or Jerusalem?) was that early mosque niches were misaligned with Mecca; this argument has been disproved by David A King
author: jricole

text: 1/10 In their 1977 "Hagarism," which they later repudiated, Michael Cook and Patricia Crone strongly implied that the Qur'an actually grew up in Palestine.  They dismiss Qur'an 48 as not locating the Kaaba in Mecca, in which they were mistaken
author: jricole

text: 1/9  The Qur'an depicts 3 periods of time-- an early one in which the Believers could visit the temple but had to share it with pagans (72:18); a middle one in Yathrib when they were barred from the Kaaba; and a final one when they regained access to the shrine at Mecca.
author: jricole

text: 1/8 Words like bayt and masjid (both probably meaning temple) occur in the chapters thought to have been set in Mecca 610-622 and are are said to refer to the Kaaba as well.
author: jricole

text: 1/7  Note that the later Muslim commentary tradition tends to view the Surat al-Fath or Chapter of Success (48) as being about the peace treaty of Hudaybiya in spring of 628, but this makes no sense since the Believers are not said then to have entered Mecca.
author: jricole

text: 1/6  The Qur'an 5:95 identifies the sacred temple as the Ka`ba.  The geography of the Qur'an seems clear.  There is someplace near Yathrib that has a sacred temple or sanctuary called Mecca, from which the Believers were barred by pagans
author: jricole

text: 1/5 The Qur'an in 48:25 complains that the pagans had earlier barred the Believers from the Sanctuary Temple (al-Masjid al-Haram), which it thus locates in Mecca.  Tradition identifies this temple as the Kaaba
author: jricole

text: 1/4  The Qur'an (48:24) says in Surat al-Fath that when Muhammad and the Believers made a peaceful procession to their holy shrine, presumably from Yathrib, there was no fighting in the sacred precincts of Mecca
author: jricole

text: Muhammad and his Quraysh are also said to have made a treaty or constitution with "the people of Yathrib" in the 'Constitution of Medina' of roughly 624, which even skeptics have tended to accept as authentic  https://ar.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D8%B5%D8%AD%D9%8A%D9%81%D8%A9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%AF%D9%8A%D9%86%D8%A9 …
